questions.text: The flap shown in the picture is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serratus anterior flap

 

The given image shows a serratus anterior flap. The serratus anterior flap is a highly reliable flap which has a consistently long pedicle. Its anatomy allows coverage of complex wounds. The underlying rib can be included as a myoosseous flap to expand the versatility of this flap.

 

  • The serratus anterior flap is a reconstructive surgical technique that uses the serratus anterior muscle, which is located between the ribs and scapula.
  • This flap is often used for chest wall reconstruction and breast reconstruction procedures.
  • It provides good vascularization and can be used to cover defects in the chest and axillary regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoral Myo-cutaneous Flap: The pectoral myo-cutaneous flap is a surgical technique that utilizes tissue from the pectoral muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is commonly used in reconstruction after resection of oral malignancies.
  • This flap can provide a good blood supply and a natural appearance.

 

Option C. TRAM Flap (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The TRAM flap is a reconstructive technique that uses tissue from the lower abdominal wall, including the rectus abdominis muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is often employed in breast reconstruction, providing a large amount of tissue.
  • There are two types: pedicled TRAM flap (retains its blood supply through the rectus muscle) and free TRAM flap (microvascular reconstruction).

 

Option D. VRAM Flap (Vertical Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The VRAM flap is similar to the TRAM flap but uses tissue from the vertical orientation of the rectus abdominis muscle.

 

  • It is also used in breast reconstruction and abdominal wall reconstruction.
  • Like the TRAM flap, it can be pedicled or free, depending on the surgical technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flap surgery is a type of plastic surgery that uses tissues from another part of the body to close open wounds while having its own blood supply.
  • The site from which the tissue is obtained is called the donor site, while the site where the tissue is transferred is called the recipient site. Flaps may be of soft tissue, skin, muscle, bone, fat or fascia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman came to the OPD with a diagnosis of advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14-year-old daughter. What advice would you give for her daughter? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Advise HPV vaccine

 

The patient's 14-year-old daughter should be advised to take the HPV vaccine.

 

Screening CA cervix begins at the age of 25 years.

 

HPV vaccine

 

  • Contains recombinant VLP (L1 synthetic capsid protein)
  • Types –
    • Cervarix: Bivalent (16,18)
    • Gardasil: Quadrivalent (6,11,16,18)
    • Gardasil 9: Nonavalent (6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58)
    • Dosing as per IAP:
      • Girls 9 to 14 years: 2 doses
      • > 15 years: 3 doses

 

On June 1, 2023 there will be the launch of Indian indigenous vaccine called Cervavac , quadrivalent vaccine produce by Serum Institute of India (6, 11, 16, 18).

 

WHO’s Safe Advisory Group (SAGE) in 2021 advised regarding updating dose schedules for HPV as follows:

 

  • One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14
  • One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20
  • Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21

 

Immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, should receive three doses if feasible, and if not at least two doses. There is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of a single dose in this group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screen for BRCA mutation: BRCA mutation causes breast cancer, ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer

 

Option C. Screen for PTEN mutation: PTEN mutation (chromosome 10) causes Cowden syndrome, has 20-30% risk of developing endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. Perform cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsy is not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine is essential for preventing cervical cancer and should be administered to girls aged 9 to 14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.

questions.text: Best test for the diagnosis of disease malaria species is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: What would be a useful diagnostic tool to consider for a patient who presented with symptoms of hair loss, itching of the scalp, and a mild discharge? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) KOH mount

 

The above image shows tinea capitis, which presents with a well-demarcated scaly patch in which hair shafts are broken off just above the skin resulting in alopecia / hair loss. KOH mount is useful for the depicted condition.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Fig: Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton associated Tinea capitis specifically is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tzanck smear:

 

  • Use: It is a microscopic examination used to identify cells from blistering skin conditions. It's especially useful in detecting herpes simplex, herpes zoster, and pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Why it's not the answer: The presented symptoms are not typical of blistering skin conditions or herpetic infections, which is where a Tzanck smear would be most useful.

 

Option B. Gram stain:

 

  • Use: This is a staining technique used to classify bacterial species into two groups (Gram-positive and Gram-negative) based on the chemical and physical properties of their cell walls.
  • Why it's not the answer: While a bacterial infection could lead to scalp discharge, the combination of hair loss and itching specifically suggests a fungal etiology over a bacterial one.

 

Option C. Slit skin smear:

 

  • Use: This test is primarily used for diagnosing leprosy by detecting Mycobacterium leprae in skin lesions.
  • Why it's not the answer: The symptoms described are not indicative of leprosy, which generally presents as skin patches with sensory loss or nerve enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.39

questions.text: Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bladder exstrophy

 

The above image is suggestive of ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy.

 

Ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. Clinical features of this condition include separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis, epispadias, and genital defects such as bifid clitoris in females and broad and short penis with bilateral inguinal hernia in males.

 

Management of bladder exstrophy involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. The first step is closure of the abdominal and bladder wall within the first year of life. This procedure may require an iliac osteotomy to relieve tension on the bladder and facilitate wound-healing. Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects may be performed. Alternatively, urinary diversion can be carried out by creating ureterosigmoid anastomosis, an ileal or colonic conduit, or continent urinary diversion.

 

Long-term complications of bladder exstrophy include stricture at the site of the anastomosis leading to bilateral hydronephrosis and infection, hyperchloremic acidosis, and an increased (20-fold) risk of tumor formation such as adenoma and adenocarcinoma at the site of a ureteroscopic anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: The abdominal contents are out and are covered in a sac. It is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect. It occurs due to the failure of the physiological umbilical hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. It is associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels and chromosomal abnormalities.

 

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct: It is a congenital anomaly that occurs during fetal development. The vitelline duct is a structure that connects the developing embryo to the yolk sac. In normal development, the vitelline duct is supposed to disappear by the time the fetus is born. However, in some cases, the duct persists and can lead to various complications.

 

Option D. gastrochisis: in this condition, the abdominal contents are out and are NOT covered in a sac.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality characterized by an open and exposed bladder due to incomplete formation of the lower abdominal wall. The management involves staged surgical reconstruction, and complications include strictures, hyperchloremic acidosis, and increased risk of tumors.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents for her routine first-trimester ultrasound at approximately 7.5 weeks of gestation. The ultrasound reveals two distinct small bubbles within the gestational sac, giving a characteristic double bleb appearance. The clinician identifies this finding and reassures the patient that it is typical for this stage of pregnancy. What is the double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Yolk sac and amniotic sac

 

The double bleb sign is a normal ultrasound finding seen in early pregnancy, specifically around 7.5 to 8 weeks of gestation. This sign is characterized by the appearance of two small bubbles within the gestational sac, representing the yolk sac and the amniotic sac.

 

Yolk Sac: The yolk sac is the first structure visible within the gestational sac and plays a vital role in providing nutrients to the developing embryo and facilitating early hematopoiesis.

 

Amniotic Sac: The amniotic sac surrounds the embryo, providing a protective environment filled with amniotic fluid, which cushions the embryo as it grows.

The presence of the double bleb sign is an important indication of a normal early intrauterine pregnancy, as it confirms the development of both the yolk sac and the amniotic sac, which are essential for embryonic growth.

 

Do Not Confuse with Double Decidual Sign:

 

The double bleb sign should not be confused with the double decidual sign, which is another ultrasound finding in early pregnancy. The double decidual sign represents a true gestational sac surrounded by two layers: the decidua capsularis and the decidua parietalis, with a fluid collection between these two layers. This sign is used to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy and distinguish it from a pseudosac seen in ectopic pregnancies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis: These layers are part of the double decidual sign, not the double bleb sign.

 

Option C. Gestational sac and yolk sac: While the yolk sac is part of the double bleb sign, the gestational sac itself does not form the second bubble.

 

Option D. Embryo and yolk sac: Although the embryo is present within the gestational sac, it does not form the characteristic double bleb sign; the amniotic sac is the other structure involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The double bleb sign in early pregnancy ultrasound is due to the presence of the yolk sac and the amniotic sac within the gestational sac. It is a normal finding that confirms early intrauterine pregnancy. The double decidual sign, on the other hand, involves the decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis, which are not part of the double bleb sign.

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • The picture depicts a trombiculid mite, known for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

SCRUB TYPHUS (ORIENTIA)

 

  • Caused by → Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector → Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)
  • Chiggerosis → Among all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Eschar (at the site of bite)
    • Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Maculopapular rash
  • DOC → Doxycycline

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kyasanur forest disease: Kyasanur forest disease is vector borne disease caused by hard tick.

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is vector borne disease transmitted by sandfly

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Anaplasma is a tick-borne disease affecting ruminants, dogs, and horses, and is caused by Anaplasma bacteria. Mainly transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans.

 

Germ tube test is a screening test for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. Candida dubliniensis can also form germ tubes and Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that closely resemble germ tubes.

 

Germ tube formation was first reported by Reynolds and Braude and hence the germ tube test is also known as Reynolds-Braude phenomenon.

 

Buds and pseudo-hyphae can be distinguished from germ tubes by the constricted attachment at the point of origin. Germ tubes don’t show constriction at the point of origin.

 

Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis produce short, slender, tube-like structures called germ tubes.

 

The formation of germ tubes is associated with increased synthesis of protein and ribonucleic acid. Various media like fetal bovine serum may be used as a substitute for human pooled serum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida glabrata: Candida glabrata does not produce germ tubes. It forms small, round yeast cells.

 

Option C. Candida parapsilosis: Candida parapsilosis does not produce germ tubes. It forms pseudohyphae and yeast cells.

 

Option D. Candida tropicalis: Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that resemble germ tubes, but they show constriction at the point of origin. This is a distinguishing feature from the true germ tubes of Candida albicans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The germ tube test is used for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. It detects the formation of germ tubes, which are characteristic of Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis but not other Candida species. Germ tubes are short, slender, tube-like structures without constriction at their point of origin, differentiating them from pseudohyphae.

questions.text:
When asked the patient to stand on left foot, right side went down. Which structures are involved in this case? (INICET NOV 2023)

 

 

 

  1. Superior gluteal nerve
  2. Gluteus minimus
  3. Gluteus medius
  4. Sciatic nerve
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

 

 

This question describes a clinical scenario where a patient is exhibiting a positive Trendelenburg sign. When asked to stand on the left foot, the patient's right side drops, indicating a problem with the muscles or nerves responsible for maintaining hip stability. The Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

 

1. Superior Gluteal Nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. Damage to this nerve can lead to weakness in these muscles.

 

2. Gluteus Minimus: This muscle, along with the gluteus medius, helps to stabilize the pelvis during walking. Weakness or paralysis of the gluteus minimus results in the inability to maintain a level pelvis.

 

3. Gluteus Medius: This muscle is crucial for hip abduction and pelvic stabilization. Weakness or paralysis causes the pelvis to drop on the side opposite to the stance leg.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve does not innervate the gluteus medius or minimus. Its primary functions involve the muscles of the posterior thigh and lower leg. Damage to the sciatic nerve would not cause a Trendelenburg sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Trendelenburg sign, where the pelvis drops on the opposite side when standing on one foot, indicates weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text: Dr. Sharma, the head of the pediatric department at a renowned medical college in Uttar Pradesh, is conducting a training session for new medical officers. As part of the session, he aims to ensure the officers are well-versed with the national health programs related to child health. He poses the question, "Under the Rashtriya Bal Swashthya Karyakram (RBSK) initiative, which of these diseases is not covered? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Congenital glaucoma

 

  • While congenital cataract is explicitly mentioned as part of the initiative's coverage, congenital glaucoma is not typically listed among the prioritized conditions for screening under the RBSK.
  • This omission might be due to the relative rarity or specific screening requirements of congenital glaucoma compared to more commonly addressed conditions in public health programs.

 

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

 

  • Importance: Child Health Screening and Early Intervention Services Program under National Rural Health Mission
  • Target group:
    • 0-6 years old children (Rural areas + Urban slums)
    • 6-18 years old children (Enrolled in government schools)
  • Targeted diseases (4D’s):
    • Defects at birth
    • Diseases in children
    • Deficiency conditions
    • Developmental delays including disabilities

 

Educational Objective:

 

Targeted diseases:

choices.text: Duration of action is longer than filgrastim
Added advantage is that it can be taken orally
It is contraindicated in patients with sickle cell anemia
It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pegylated-filgrastim? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duration of action is longer than filgrastim

 

  • Pegylated-filgrastim, also known as peg-filgrastim, is a long-acting formulation of filgrastim that is used to stimulate the production of white blood cells in patients receiving chemotherapy. The addition of polyethylene glycol (PEG) to filgrastim increases its molecular weight and slows down its clearance from the body, resulting in a longer duration of action compared to normal filgrastim.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Added advantage is that it can be taken orally:  Pegylated-filgrastim cannot be taken orally, as it is administered by injection.

 

Option C. It is contraindicated in patients with sickle cell anemia: Pegylated-filgrastim is not contraindicated in sickle cell patients, but caution should be exercised as it can stimulate the production of white blood cells, increasing the risk of sickling crises.

 

Option D. It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia: Pegylated-filgrastim is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia and can help to reduce the risk of infection in patients undergoing chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegylated-filgrastim has a longer duration of action than regular filgrastim due to its pegylation, which slows its clearance from the body. It is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia and is administered by injection, not orally. While not contraindicated in sickle cell anemia, caution is advised due to the potential risk of stimulating white blood cell production and increasing the risk of sickling crises.

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal laryngeal nerve

 

Cough reflex is a protective mechanism of the larynx to expel foreign irritants in order to keep airway clear. Afferent of this reflex is through internal laryngeal nerve, which gives sensory supply to mucosa above vocal cords. Irritant substances like alcohol affects the nervous system causing inhibition of cough reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Primarily involved in the sensation and taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue, not directly involved in the cough reflex at the larynx.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: Mainly supplies the cricothyroid muscle with motor fibers and does not have a sensory role in the cough reflex.

 

Option D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa below the vocal cords; thus, it plays a role in the cough reflex but primarily for the lower part of the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to or inhibition of the internal laryngeal nerve can significantly impair the cough reflex by reducing the sensory input required to detect irritants above the vocal cords, emphasizing its pivotal role in this protective reflex.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 337

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toluidine and malachite green

 

Albert stain is used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria, such as those seen in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The staining technique involves two solutions: Albert stain 1 and Albert stain 2. Albert stain 1 contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, which are basic dyes with a high affinity for acidic tissue components like cytoplasm. Toluidine blue stains the granules blue, while Malachite green provides a green background. This differential staining helps in visualizing the metachromatic granules distinctly.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbol fuschin and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect as Carbol fuschin is used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining for acid-fast bacteria, and methylene blue is a counterstain in that procedure.

 

Option B. Carbol fuschin and malachite green: This combination is incorrect because Carbol fuschin is not used in Albert staining; it is used in acid-fast staining procedures.

 

Option D. Toluidine and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect for Albert staining. Methylene blue is a basic dye used in various other staining techniques, but not in Albert stain.

 

Educational Objective:


Albert stain contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

choices.text: Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 wks
Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete.
Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with 35 weeks+5 days gestation complains of epigastric pain, headache, and blurring of vision. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. She is in labor pain. Examination of the cervix shows a 3 cm dilatation with a bag of liquor. What is the appropriate management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy.

 

This pregnant woman is presenting with symptoms and signs of severe pre-eclampsia, which include:

 

  • Epigastric pain
  • Headache
  • Blurring of vision
  • Severe hypertension: Blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg.

 

In the context of severe pre-eclampsia at 35 weeks+5 days gestation, the management should include:

 

  • Treating hypertension: Immediate blood pressure control is crucial to prevent complications such as eclampsia, stroke, or placental abruption.
  • Administering magnesium sulfate (MgSO4): This is done to prevent eclamptic seizures.
  • Consideration for termination of pregnancy: In cases of severe pre-eclampsia at or beyond 34 weeks, the recommended course of action is to expedite delivery to prevent further maternal and fetal complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative management: Conservative management is not appropriate for severe pre-eclampsia due to the high risk of complications for both the mother and the fetus.

 

Option B. Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks: Tocolytics are contraindicated in severe pre-eclampsia as the goal is to deliver the baby as soon as the condition is stable, rather than delaying delivery.

 

Option C. Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete: As the patient is already beyond 34 weeks of gestation, steroid administration for fetal lung maturity is not necessary, and immediate delivery is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe pre-eclampsia at or beyond 34 weeks of gestation, immediate management involves controlling hypertension, administering magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures, and expediting delivery.

 

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1850,  Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg267

Among the given options, the best answer will be option B.

Educational Objective:

 

Increased CRP levels are positively associated with an increased risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and stroke. As CRP levels rise, the relative risk of these conditions also increases.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland. This tumor is composed of a mix of ductal and myoepithelial cells, often presenting as a painless, progressive, firm mass typically located in the superolateral aspect of the orbit.

 

Details about Pleomorphic Adenoma:

 

  • Benign Nature: Despite its benign nature, pleomorphic adenoma can cause displacement of the eye and may alter vision due to its size and location.
  • Potential for Malignant Transformation: While it is primarily benign, there is a risk for malignant transformation into a carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if not adequately treated or if left untreated for a long duration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Although this is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland, it is not as frequently occurring as pleomorphic adenoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known for its aggressive nature and poorer prognosis.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: This type of tumor can involve the lacrimal gland but is generally less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This is another type of malignant tumor that can occur in the lacrimal gland, but it is also less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the lacrimal gland. Overall, benign tumours are more common, thus pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumour.
