questions.text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuromyelitis optica

 

Bilateral optic neuritis with extensive transverse myelitis and partial steroid response is suggestive of NMO-Spectrum disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MS usually causes U/L optic neuritis. LETM (Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis) not common in MS.

 

Option C. SACD usually affects the posterior column. LETM, optic neuritis not a feature of B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Neurosyphilis is usually associated with RAPD (U/L Optic neuritis). LETM not common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINGERCHUK Criteria for NMO-SD

questions.text: A researcher in epidemiology is planning to conduct a meta-analysis to better understand the effects of a specific intervention. While he lists the various stages and processes associated with a meta-analysis, he includes one element that isn't typically involved in a meta-analysis. Which of the following isn't directly associated with the process of a meta-analysis? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Randomization 

 

  • Randomization is not a part of the meta-analysis process but is a critical component of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), which may be included in a meta-analysis.
  • Meta-analysis involves analysis of multiple studies together.
  • Steps of Meta-analysis involves Hypothesis formation, Study selection, Formulation of data, Analysis of data, examining bias, formulating conclusion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selection: Involves selecting studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Option B. Analysis: Involves statistical analysis of the combined data from the selected studies.

 

Option D. Abstraction: Involves extracting data from the studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Randomization is a part of conducting individual randomized controlled trials, not the process of performing a meta-analysis.

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Babesia

 

Babesia is not an intracellular parasite of hepatocytes. It is an intra-erythrocytic parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Toxoplasma gondii can infect hepatocytes as part of its lifecycle.

 

Option B. Plasmodium: The liver stage (hepatic schizogony) of Plasmodium involves hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Leishmania species infect macrophages, which can reside in the liver, leading to intracellular infection in hepatocytes indirectly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obligate intracellular parasites-

 

  • Trypanosoma cruzi
  • Leishmania spp.
  • Plasmodium spp.
  • Babesia spp. -> RBC
  • Toxoplasma gondii
  • Microsporidia

questions.text: A nutritionist is counseling a patient on the energy expenditure associated with digesting and assimilating different nutrients. The patient asks which type of nutrient requires the most energy for the body to process. Based on the body's metabolic requirements, which of the following requires the maximum energy for assimilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Proteins

 

Proteins are complex macromolecules composed of long chains of amino acids linked by peptide bonds. Among the different nutrients, proteins require the most energy for assimilation due to the extensive process needed to break them down and utilize their components.

 

  1. Digestion Process: The digestion of proteins begins in the stomach, where enzymes like pepsin break down the proteins into smaller polypeptides. This process continues in the small intestine with proteases and peptidases that further break down these polypeptides into individual amino acids. This multi-step breakdown is energy-intensive, requiring significant enzymatic activity and metabolic energy.
  2. Metabolic Utilization: Once proteins are broken down into amino acids, they are absorbed into the bloodstream and utilized in various metabolic processes. Amino acids are used for the synthesis of new proteins, enzymes, hormones, and other critical molecules. They can also be used for energy production through gluconeogenesis, a process that further demands metabolic energy.
  3. Energy Requirement: The assimilation of proteins demands more energy compared to other nutrients because the body not only needs to digest them but also needs to convert amino acids into usable forms, manage nitrogen waste products, and engage in complex metabolic pathways that are crucial for the body's functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamins: Vitamins are essential micronutrients that are absorbed directly with minimal energy expenditure compared to macronutrients. They do not require breakdown into simpler units like proteins.

 

Option B. Fats: Fats are broken down into fatty acids and glycerol during digestion, which requires less energy compared to protein digestion. Fats primarily serve as a long-term energy source and are stored efficiently.

 

Option D. Nucleic acids: Nucleic acids are digested into nucleotides, which require minimal energy compared to the complex breakdown of proteins into amino acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteins require the maximum energy for assimilation among the nutrients listed because of their complex structure and the extensive metabolic processes involved in breaking them down into individual amino acids. Understanding the energy demands of different nutrients helps in managing diet and optimizing metabolism.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing populations targeted by the HIV sentinel surveillance program. Which group is NOT traditionally included in HIV sentinel surveillance? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) STD clinic attendees

 

  • Routine monitoring for HIV is generally not conducted among individuals visiting STD clinics.
  • Sentinel surveillance serves to enhance the existing notification systems employed for disease surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single male migrants: Included in sentinel surveillance as they are considered at high risk.

 

Option B. Truck drivers: Included due to their high-risk behavior.

 

Option D. Antenatal women: Included to monitor HIV prevalence among pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sites for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

 

  • A pregnant woman of reproductive age and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.
  • Female sex workers.
  • Hijra/Transgenders.
  • IV drug users
  • Truckers.
  • Homosexual Men
  • Migrants.

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human gonadotropin. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

  • The image is a transvaginal ultrasound showing the ovaries which appear significantly enlarged with fluid in the pelvic cavity (the black spaces seen in between the ovaries)
  • In view of her history of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation in IVF, the answer is OHSS
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability and leakage of intravascular fluid to the third space.
    • It is commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH or HCG injections.
    • Multiple enlarged follicles are arranged in a necklace pattern in bilateral ovaries.
    • The mainstay of management is conservative. The ongoing stimulation cycle is suspended, and further administration of exogenous gonadotropins are stopped in that cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Theca lutein cysts: Enlarged cysts seen in molar pregnancy, not related to the provided scenario or ultrasound findings.

 

Option C. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a risk factor for OHSS, but given the history and the ultrasound image, OHSS is the more appropriate answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OHSS is characterized by multiple enlarged ovarian follicles and fluid accumulation in the pelvic cavity, often occurring after exogenous gonadotropin administration in infertility treatments.

 

Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pawlik grip

 

  • The Leopold's third manuever is also called the Pawlik's grip.
  • It is performed by grasping with the thumb and fingers, the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt.

 

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers):

 

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿1st pelvic grip / Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Second Pelvic grip: This is incorrect. The second pelvic grip, also known as the fourth Leopold maneuver, is used to determine the degree of fetal descent and engagement.

 

Option B. Abdominal grip: This term is not specific to any of the Leopold maneuvers and is not used in this context.

 

Option D. Fundal grip: This is the first Leopold maneuver, used to determine the fetal part located in the fundus of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pawlik grip (third Leopold maneuver) involves grasping the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis to assess the engagement of the presenting part of the fetus.

 

Ref: Page no 89-90, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following would most likely lead to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Squatting

 

In hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the intensity of the murmur is influenced by the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. Various maneuvers and medications can affect this obstruction by altering preload (the volume of blood in the ventricles before contraction) or afterload (the resistance the heart must pump against).

 

Squatting increases preload by squeezing the peripheral veins and increasing venous return to the heart. This increase in preload reduces LVOT obstruction, thereby decreasing the murmur's intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Digoxin increases contractility. In HCM, increased contractility can worsen LVOT obstruction, thereby increasing the intensity of the murmur and worsening the murmur.

 

Option C. Valsalva: The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload by decreasing venous return to the heart. This reduction in preload can increase LVOT obstruction, leading to a louder murmur.

 

Option D. Furosemide: By reducing preload, furosemide increases LVOT obstruction and murmur intensity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing preload (e.g., through squatting) reduces LVOT obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, leading to a decrease in the murmur's intensity.

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry
Complete blood count (CBC)

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred diagnostic tool for screening metabolic diseases, particularly inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), in children. This technology allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple metabolic disorders by measuring the levels of various metabolites in a single blood sample.

 

The high sensitivity and specificity of tandem mass spectrometry make it an ideal choice for newborn screening programs. It can detect a wide range of metabolic disorders early, enabling prompt intervention that can prevent severe complications and improve long-term outcomes. The method works by ionizing chemical compounds and then analyzing the ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio, which allows for precise identification and quantification of different substances in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete blood count (CBC): CBC is a basic test that measures different components of the blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. While it provides essential information about overall health and can help diagnose various conditions, it is not specific or sensitive enough for screening metabolic diseases.

 

Option C. Urinalysis: Urinalysis is a common test that examines the content of urine. It can help detect some metabolic disorders but is not as comprehensive or effective as tandem mass spectrometry for screening a wide range of metabolic diseases.

 

Option D. Genetic testing: Genetic testing is used to identify specific genetic mutations that may cause metabolic disorders. While it can confirm a diagnosis, it is not typically used as the primary screening tool due to its complexity and the time required for analysis. Genetic testing is more often used after an initial screening suggests the presence of a metabolic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children due to its ability to detect multiple metabolic disorders from a single blood sample.

questions.text: Relapse is seen in? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasmodium viva and ovale

 

Malaria relapse:

 

  • In case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which multiply inside hepatic cells to form schizonts and others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites.
  • True relapse is caused due to hypnozoites (resting forms). Some get activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In case of Plasmodium falciparum and malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium vivax and falciparum: While P. vivax can cause relapse, P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites and therefore does not cause relapse.

 

Option B. Plasmodium ovale and falciparum: P. ovale can cause relapse due to hypnozoites, but P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax and malariae: P. vivax causes relapse due to hypnozoites, but P. malariae does not form hypnozoites and does not cause relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relapse in malaria is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale due to the presence of hypnozoites, the dormant liver stages that can reactivate and cause renewed infection.

choices.text: Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing
Telomerase is found in somatic cells

questions.text: True about telomeres and telomerase is:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing

 

This statement is correct. Telomeres naturally shorten with each cell division, and this gradual shortening is associated with the aging process. It's a result of the end replication problem, where the DNA replication machinery cannot fully replicate the ends of linear chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased telomere length with ageing: This statement is incorrect. Telomeres, the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, tend to shorten with each cell division and are associated with aging. Over time, this can contribute to cellular senescence and aging.

 

Option C. Telomeres have coding sequences: This statement is incorrect. Telomeres do not contain coding sequences for proteins. Instead, they consist of repetitive DNA sequences that provide a buffer zone to protect the essential genetic information during cell division.

 

Option D. Telomerase is found in somatic cells: This statement is generally incorrect. Telomerase, the enzyme that can counteract telomere shortening by adding repetitive DNA sequences, is typically more active in germ cells and certain stem cells. In most somatic cells, telomerase activity is low, contributing to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each cell division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomeres are end of chromosomes and do not contain any coding sequences. Instead it has TTAGGG sequence repeated ‘n’ no. of times.

 

Telomerase is enzyme present only in the germ/stem cells and is responsible for maintaining the length of telomeres due to its RNA dependent DNA polymerase activity.

 

In Somatic cells, absence of telomerase enzyme (option d is false) results in telomere shortening as the cells ages.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 355, 716

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly male patient who received a kidney transplant a decade ago is presently under immunosuppressive treatment. He reports experiencing a persistent cough and shortness of breath over the past week. Microscopic examination of his sputum reveals the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the probable diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive candidiasis

 

  • The presented clinical scenario, coupled with the microscopy revealing gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae, strongly indicates the presence of invasive candidiasis.
  • Candida albicans has a unique ability to transform frequently between three phenotypic forms in the tissue: yeast, pseudohyphae, true hyphae. This property helps it to evade host defense system.
  • Invasive candidiasis results from hematogenous or local spread of the fungi.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor shows, broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching.

 

Option B. Aspergillus shows septate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive candidiasis is characterized by the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae in tissue or clinical specimens, especially in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is high-molecular weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to integrins? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibronectin

 

Fibronectin is a high-molecular weight (~500-~600 kDa) glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to membrane-spanning receptor proteins called integrins.

 

Integrins are cell surface receptors that play a crucial role in connecting cells to their extracellular environment, including other cells and the extracellular matrix (ECM). Integrins can connect with several types of molecules and proteins, including:

 

  1. Extracellular Matrix (ECM) Proteins: Integrins can bind to various components of the ECM, such as fibronectin, laminin, collagen, and vitronectin. These interactions allow cells to anchor to the ECM and provide structural support.
  2. Cell Adhesion Molecules: Integrins can connect with other cell adhesion molecules on neighbouring cells, promoting cell-cell interactions and the formation of multicellular structures. Examples of cell adhesion molecules include cadherins, selectins, and immunoglobulin superfamily proteins.
  3. Signalling Proteins: Integrins can also associate with intracellular signalling proteins, such as focal adhesion kinases (FAK), Src family kinases, and various adapter proteins. These interactions transmit signals from the ECM to the cell's interior, influencing cellular processes like cell growth, migration, and differentiation.
  4. Blood Clotting Factors: In platelets, integrins can bind to fibrinogen and von Willebrand factor, contributing to platelet aggregation and blood clot formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cadherin: Involved in calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion.

 

Option B. Vitronectin: Also a part of the extracellular matrix but known for its role in serum spreading factor and in the promotion of cell adhesion and spreading.

 

Option D. Selectin: Plays a role in cell adhesion during the immune response, particularly in the binding of white blood cells to the endothelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibronectin is a key component of the extracellular matrix that interacts with cell surface integrins to mediate various cellular processes including adhesion, migration, and tissue repair.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the ER with menorrhagia. She mentions that her father and sister also suffer from bleeding disorders. Which of the following is likely? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Von Willebrand Disease

 

Von Willebrand Disease (vWD) is the most likely diagnosis given the family history of bleeding disorders and the patient's presentation with menorrhagia. vWD is an autosomal dominant condition affecting both males and females, characterized by defective platelet function due to a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor. This leads to symptoms such as prolonged bleeding, menorrhagia, and prolonged bleeding after dental extractions or surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor X deficiency: An extremely rare autosomal recessive condition that typically presents with joint bleeding (hemarthrosis) and intramuscular hematomas, which are more indicative of coagulation disorders rather than bleeding tendencies seen in platelet disorders.

 

Option B. Factor VIII deficiency: Known as Hemophilia A, this is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting mostly males. Females are typically carriers and rarely show symptoms. Hemophilia A presents with severe bleeding episodes and hemarthrosis, not usually menorrhagia.

 

Option C. Factor IX deficiency: Known as Hemophilia B, this is also an X-linked recessive disorder affecting mostly males, with similar presentations to Hemophilia A, including severe bleeding episodes and hemarthrosis, not typically menorrhagia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand Disease is an autosomal dominant disorder presenting with bleeding symptoms like menorrhagia and is more common in females compared to Hemophilia A or B, which are X-linked recessive and primarily affect males.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with progressive hearing loss and persistent tinnitus in the right ear. He reports difficulty understanding conversations and occasional episodes of dizziness. Physical examination is unremarkable, but audiometric testing shows sensorineural hearing loss on the right side. An MRI reveals a mass at the cerebellopontine angle. A biopsy is performed, and the histological image provided shows distinctive features of the tumor. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acoustic neuroma

 

Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a benign, encapsulated, and slow-growing tumor that arises from Schwann cells, usually at the cerebellopontine angle. It is most commonly associated with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes vertigo. Histologically, it features Antoni A and Antoni B areas, with Antoni A areas showing hypercellular regions containing Verocay bodies—two rows of parallel nuclei with an anuclear zone in between. This pattern is characteristic and helps differentiate acoustic neuroma from other similar tumors.

 

Clinical Features:


Typically presents with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes vertigo. These symptoms result from the tumor’s slow growth and its effect on the vestibulocochlear nerve. The tumor may also involve the 5th cranial nerve, leading to a loss of the corneal reflex.

 

Origin:


Acoustic neuromas originate from Schwann cells, which are derived from neural crest cells, specifically from the inferior vestibular nerve.

 

Marker:


These tumors are positive for the S-100 protein, a marker used to confirm Schwann cell origin in histopathological evaluation.

 

Investigation:


The preferred diagnostic test is a contrast-enhanced MRI, which reveals the mass's size and location at the cerebellopontine angle. Audiometric tests, such as pure tone audiometry, indicate sensorineural hearing loss, and speech audiometry may show poor speech discrimination.

 

On Biopsy:


Histologically, acoustic neuromas are characterized by the presence of Antoni A areas, which are densely cellular with Verocay bodies, and Antoni B areas, which are less cellular and myxoid. This unique histological appearance helps confirm the diagnosis of Schwannoma.

 

Treatment:


Treatment typically involves Gamma Knife surgery, a non-invasive form of stereotactic radiosurgery that targets the tumor with precision, or traditional microsurgical removal for larger or more symptomatic tumors.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningioma: Meningiomas are tumors that arise from the meninges, typically presenting without the specific histological features of Antoni A and B areas with Verocay bodies seen in acoustic neuroma.

 

Option C. Paraganglioma: These are highly vascular tumors that often present with a "salt and pepper" appearance on imaging and do not show the histological patterns seen in acoustic neuromas.

 

Option D. Epidermoid cyst: These are slow-growing lesions with a characteristic bright signal on diffusion-weighted MRI imaging and are histologically distinct, lacking the Antoni areas and Verocay bodies of acoustic neuromas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuroma presents with unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and histological features of Antoni A and B areas with Verocay bodies. Proper diagnosis relies on imaging and histological findings, with surgical intervention often required for management.

questions.text: The type of fibers present in the fornix are? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Association and commisural fibers

 

All of the fornix's fibres are association fibres, with the exception of the hippocampal commissure, which possesses commissural fibres. As a result, option A—both association and commissural fibers—is the best response.

 

Association fibers connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere whereas commissural fibers connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

 

Fornix arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus. Its blood supply - anterior cerebral artery.

 

Note: The function of the commissure of the fornix is to connect the hippocampal formations of the two sides.

 

 

  • The commissural fibers or transverse fibers: are axons that connect the two hemispheres of the brain.
  • Association fibers: connect regions within the same hemisphere of the brain
  • Projection fibers: connect each region to other parts of the brain or to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Association and Projection fibers: Projection fibers: These fibers connect the cerebral cortex to the lower brain regions and spinal cord. They are mainly involved in conveying information between the cerebral cortex and other parts of the CNS. The fornix doesn't primarily contain projection fibers; its main constituents are association and commissural fibers.

 

Option C. Commissural and Projection fibers: As previously stated, while the fornix contains commissural fibers, it doesn't mainly contain projection fibers.

 

Option D. Association fibers: Association fibers, as mentioned, connect different parts of the same hemisphere. The fornix does contain association fibers, but it's not limited to just these; it also has commissural fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix contains both association fibers (linking parts of the hippocampus to other regions within the same hemisphere) and commissural fibers (connecting the hippocampi of the two hemispheres).

 

Association fibers: These fibers connect different parts of the same hemisphere. Their function is to enable communication between different cortical areas within the same cerebral hemisphere.

 

Commissural fibers: These are axons that connect one cerebral hemisphere to the other. Their primary function is to allow the two hemispheres to communicate with each other. The corpus callosum is the most significant group of commissural fibers, but the fornix also contains commissural fibers. Specifically, fibers from the fornix contribute to the hippocampal commissure, which connects the two hippocampi of the right and left hemispheres.

questions.text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 69 XXY

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are characterized by being triploid, meaning they have three sets of chromosomes. The chromosome number for a partial mole is typically 69, which can be either 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

  • Formation of Partial Mole:
    • Partial moles occur when two sperm fertilize a single ovum (egg). This process is called diandry.
    • As a result, both maternal and paternal genetic components are present in a partial mole.
    • The most common karyotypes for partial moles are 69XXX and 69XXY.
  • Complete Mole Characteristics:
    • Complete moles are diploid, meaning they have two sets of chromosomes.
    • They form either by:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum and then undergoing duplication, a process known as androgenesis, or
      • Two sperm (dispermy) fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum.
    • The chromosome number for complete moles is typically 46XX or 46XY.
    • Only the paternal genetic component is present, with no maternal contribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 46 XX: This karyotype is typical for a complete mole, not a partial mole.

 

Option B. 45 XY: This karyotype is not typical for either complete or partial moles.

 

Option C. 69 XY: This option is incorrect as partial moles can be 69XY, but 69XXY is more specific and typical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are triploid, typically having a chromosome number of 69, which can be 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

Ref: Page no 616, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roenne's nasal step

 

  • Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma.
  • Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field.

 

Roenne’s nasal step

 

 

  • Early glaucomatous changes:
    • Increase in cup-disc ratio (C/D ratio) to >0.4
    • Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin
    • Atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Advanced glaucomatous changes:
    • Marked increase in C/D ratio (0.7 or more)
    • Thinning of the neuroretinal rim
    • Nasal shifting of the retinal vessels or bayonetting
    • Pulsations of retinal arterioles at the disc margin.
    • If the damage progresses, all neural tissue is destroyed and the optic nerve appears white and deeply excavated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bayonetting: This refers to the appearance of blood vessels on the optic disc where the vessels appear to sharply bend or 'bayonet' due to the structural changes in the optic disc from glaucomatous damage, particularly as the neuroretinal rim thins and the cup enlarges.

 

Option C. Increased cup-disc ratio: A hallmark of glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve, where the optic cup enlarges relative to the overall disc, often exceeding a ratio of 0.5, which is considered abnormal and suggestive of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Baring of nasal arteries: This describes the exposure or baring of the nasal retinal arteries as a result of thinning of the nerve fiber layer in glaucoma. It is a less commonly described feature compared to others but can occur as part of the broader pattern of optic nerve head changes in glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roenne's nasal step, while indicative of the functional impact of glaucoma, does not represent a direct observation of the optic disc but is rather a manifestation of the disease's effect on the visual field.

questions.text: Identify the ‘1’ in the picture: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoid Macular Edema

 

  • Cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina centred around the fovea with the formation of tiny cyst-like cavities forming a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography.
  • CME develops due to leakage of fluid following breakdown of inner blood-retinal barrier (i.e., leakage from the retinal capillaries).
  • It is associated with a number of disorders, including postoperative complications following cataract extraction and penetrating keratoplasty, retinal vascular disorders (e.g., diabetic retinopathy and central retinal vein occlusion), intraocular inflammations (e.g., pars planitis, posterior uveitis, Behcet disease), side effects of drugs (e.g., following use of adrenaline eyedrops, especially for aphakic glaucoma, and retinal dystrophies (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa).
  • Clinical manifestations of CME include visual loss, which may be initially minimal to moderate and un-associated with other symptoms, but can progress to permanent decrease in vision if edema persists.
  • CME is best examined with a fundus contact lens on slit-lamp or +90D lens, and typically presents a "Honey-comb appearance" of macula due to multiple cystoid oval spaces on ophthalmoscopy.

 

 

 

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography demonstrates leakage and accumulation of dye in the macular region, which in a well-established case presents a "flower petal appearance".

 

 

Cystoid macular edema (CME) and central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) are two conditions that can affect the macula, the central part of the retina. Here is a table comparing the two conditions:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macular Hole: This would appear as a dark or black spot in the center of the macula due to a full-thickness opening in the retina, which is not observed in this image.

 

Option C. Smoke stack pattern: This pattern would be typical of central serous chorioretinopathy and is characterized by a well-defined, localized leakage point causing fluid to ascend vertically, not seen here.

 

Option D. Age related Macular Degeneration: Typically shows drusen, geographic atrophy, or neovascularization, none of which are evident in this fluorescein angiography image as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) often presents with a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography due to pooling of dye in cystic spaces of the macula and is associated with various underlying conditions affecting the vascular integrity of the retina.

choices.text: Binding to beta subunit of Hb

questions.text: 2,3-BPG causes the unloading of oxygen to tissues by?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Binding to beta subunit of Hb

 

2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) causes the unloading of oxygen to tissues by binding to the beta subunit of hemoglobin (Hb). This binding decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, thereby facilitating the release of oxygen to the tissues.

 

  • 2,3-BPG Role: 2,3-BPG is a byproduct of glycolysis in red blood cells (RBCs) and plays a crucial role in regulating oxygen delivery. It binds to the deoxygenated form of hemoglobin, stabilizing it and promoting the release of oxygen.

 

  • Binding to Beta Subunit: 2,3-BPG binds specifically to the beta subunits of hemoglobin in the central cavity formed by the four subunits. This interaction stabilizes the T (tense) state of hemoglobin, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thus promoting oxygen unloading.

 

  • Physiological Conditions: Conditions such as high altitude and exercise increase the levels of 2,3-BPG in RBCs, enhancing oxygen release to meet the increased metabolic demand of tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increasing ATP production: This is incorrect because 2,3-BPG does not directly increase ATP production. It is a byproduct of glycolysis but its primary role in this context is to modulate hemoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option C. Inhibiting taut structure: This is incorrect because 2,3-BPG actually stabilizes the T (tense) state of hemoglobin, which is the low-affinity state.

 

Option D. Decreasing ATP production: This is incorrect as 2,3-BPG's function in oxygen unloading is not related to altering ATP production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) binds to the beta subunits of hemoglobin, decreasing its affinity for oxygen and promoting oxygen release to the tissues. This mechanism is crucial for adapting to conditions requiring increased oxygen delivery, such as high altitude and exercise.

questions.text: A man exposes his genitalia to a female passerby on the road. This method of deriving sexual gratification by observing the people that look at him nude is best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibitionism

 

The given history is suggestive of exhibitionism. Exhibitionism is a condition where an individual derives sexual gratification by exposing their genitalia to unsuspecting people and observing their reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voyeurism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification by watching others, typically women, engaged in sexual activity or in a state of undress. The person engaging in this behavior is known as a "peeping tom."
  • Punishment: Punishable under Section 354(C) IPC.

 

Option B. Fetishism

 

  • Definition: Sexual arousal and gratification are achieved through objects or specific body parts, such as footwear, undergarments, etc., often belonging to the opposite sex.

 

Option D. Masochism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification is obtained through experiencing pain or humiliation inflicted upon oneself.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following supplement is required more for a lactating woman than the pregnant female? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Vitamin A


During lactation, the mother's body requires additional nutrients to support breast milk production, which provides all necessary nutrients for the growing infant. Some nutrient needs increase more during lactation than pregnancy.

 

Comparison of Nutritional Requirements:

 

Vitamin A:

Needed for:

  • Infant vision development
  • Immune function
  • Epithelial integrity

Significantly increased loss through breast milk

Hence, greater requirement in lactation than pregnancy

 

Others options:


B12, Calcium, and Thiamine requirements increase only slightly or remain the same.

Vitamin A shows the most significant increase.

 

Educational Objective: 

Vitamin A is required more for a lactating woman than a pregnant female. This increased need ensures that there is enough vitamin A in breast milk to support the baby's growth and development, particularly for their immune system and vision.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. An initial ultrasound revealed a renal mass lesion, and a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) was performed as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Angiomyolipoma

 

The CT image shows a well-circumscribed renal mass with areas of low attenuation, indicating the presence of fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat within the lesion, which is seen as areas of negative Hounsfield units (black in color) on the CT scan, is highly suggestive of an angiomyolipoma. This characteristic feature distinguishes angiomyolipoma from other renal masses.

 

Key Features:

 

  1. Macroscopic Fat: The presence of fat within the lesion, resulting in negative Hounsfield units on CT, is a hallmark of angiomyolipoma. This feature is specific to angiomyolipomas and helps in differentiating them from other renal tumors.
  2. Well-Circumscribed Lesion: Angiomyolipomas are typically well-defined and do not invade surrounding structures, which is visible in the imaging provided.
  3. Association with Syndromes: Angiomyolipomas are often associated with tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder that may present with other features such as subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and skin manifestations like adenoma sebaceum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC): RCCs are typically hypervascular and can show necrosis, hemorrhage, or calcification. They do not commonly contain macroscopic fat, unlike angiomyolipomas.

 

Option C. Oncocytoma: Oncocytomas are benign renal tumors that may have a central scar, but they do not contain fat and do not present with negative Hounsfield units on imaging.

 

Option D. Chromophobe RCC: This subtype of RCC is characterized by solid and homogeneous masses, often with a well-defined margin, but without macroscopic fat, distinguishing it from angiomyolipoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angiomyolipomas are benign renal tumors characterized by the presence of macroscopic fat, seen as low attenuation areas on CT scans. This feature is key in differentiating them from other renal masses such as RCCs and oncocytomas. Understanding these imaging characteristics aids in the accurate diagnosis and management of renal lesions.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. An X-ray was ordered and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cephalhematoma

 

Cephalohematomas are traumatic subperiosteal hematoma of the skull that are usually caused by birth injury. They are bound between the periosteum and cranium, and therefore cannot cross sutures. Being bound by a suture line distinguishes them from subgaleal hematoma, which can cross sutures.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subgaleal hematoma: This hematoma is located beneath the scalp's aponeurotic layer and can spread widely over the skull, which is not confined by suture lines. Therefore, it is less likely to present as a localized swelling.

 

Option C. Encephalocele: This is a neural tube defect characterized by the herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull. It is usually more severe and associated with neurological deficits.

 

Option D. Caput Succedaneum: This refers to swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp, which develops as the baby travels through the birth canal. This swelling can cross suture lines and typically resolves without intervention within the first few days of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cephalhematoma is a localized hematoma under the periosteum of the skull bone in newborns, confined by suture lines and typically associated with birth trauma.

questions.text: Most radio-resistant phase of cell cycle? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S

 

This is the synthesis phase, where DNA replication occurs. Cells in S phase are considered the most radio-resistant because they have already duplicated their genetic material, making them less susceptible to radiation-induced damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G1 (Gap 1) Phase: Cells in the G1 phase are generally sensitive to radiation because they are actively engaged in normal metabolic activities and are preparing for DNA synthesis in the subsequent S phase.

 

Option C. G2 (Gap 2) Phase: The G2 phase is a period of further preparation for cell division (mitosis). Quite radiosensitive, due to checkpoint activation.

 

Option D. M Phase (Mitosis): This is the phase where cell division occurs, and the cell divides into two daughter cells. Cells in M phase are most sensitive to radiation.

choices.text: Direct observation with a structured checklist
In-depth interview with the healthcare provider

questions.text: A newly established hospital aims to maintain the highest standards of care and ensure patient safety by standardizing injection practices among health workers. They seek a reliable method for real-time assessment of these practices. Which of the following would be the most appropriate method to monitor the injection practices of health workers? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Direct observation with a structured checklist

 

  • The most effective approach for assessing the injection practices of healthcare workers is through direct observation using a structured checklist.
  • This method allows for real-time, accurate assessment of adherence to aseptic techniques and best practices.
  • A structured checklist ensures all critical steps are monitored and recorded systematically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Closed circuit camera surveillance: While it may offer some insights, it lacks the detail and real-time assessment provided by direct observation.

 

Option C. In-depth interview with the patient: Patients may not have the expertise to accurately comment on the technical aspects of injection practices.

 

Option D. In-depth interview with the healthcare provider: This relies on self-reporting, which may be biased and not always accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most effective approach for assessing the injection practices of healthcare workers is through direct observation using a structured checklist.

questions.text:
A woman presented with morning stiffness that gradually resolves over one hour. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. NSAIDs can improve the symptoms and have disease modifying activity.
  2. Absence of erosion rules out the diagnosis.
  3. It is associated with raised ESR and CRP.
  4. HLA DR4 is related to the prognosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) III, IV are correct

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis
      • Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
         
  • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
    • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Usually DIP is not involved in and is not used for diagnosis but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
    • Lumbar Spine is usually spared.
       
  • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
  • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers
       
  • Treatment:
    • Exercises to maintain muscle strength and joint mobility.
    • NSAIDs
    • Glucocorticoid therapy esp. in vasculitis.
    • Immunosuppressive therapy by leflunomide, DMARDs, methotrexate (drug of choice), anticytokine, etanercept, cyclosporine, infliximab, adalimumab, abatacept.

 

Other Options:

 

  • NSAIDs are anti-inflammatory drugs and not disease-modifying drugs. NSAIDs are used for symptomatic treatment in RA. They have few side effects but also have potential adverse effects like GI bleeding.
  • Bone erosion is a central feature of rheumatoid arthritis and is associated with disease severity and poor functional outcome. Erosion of periarticular cortical bone, the typical feature observed on plain radiographs in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, results from excessive local bone resorption and inadequate bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis presents with raised serum ESR and quantitative CRP levels, and HLA DR4 positivity.

questions.text: A first year MBBS student presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of impending doom accompanied by profuse sweating. The episodes usually occur before her exams. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic disorder

 

The symptoms described are indicative of panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort that may include palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, and feelings of impending doom. These attacks can occur unexpectedly or in anticipation of a specific trigger, such as before an exam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms not explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition.

 

Option C. Social anxiety disorder is characterized by an intense fear of social situations.

 

Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive anxiety and worry about multiple events or activities most days for at least 6 months, not limited to performance situations like exams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of panic attack. Panic attack is a sudden, intense episode of fear or discomfort often accompanied by a sensation of impending doom. The symptoms during panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and feeling of unreality (depersonalization or derealization).Along with these physical symptoms there is also fear of dying, losing control or going mad.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 394.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is being treated for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin presented with complaints of sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness. The finding of the ultrasound is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG  2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

The given clinical situation and USG showing enlarged ovaries having large cysts points to diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

 

OVARIAN HYPERSTIMULATION SYNDROME

 

  • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation.
  • The clinical features appear about 3–6 days after the ovulating dose of hCG is administered.
  • Pathophysiology - Increased capillary permeability leads to leakage of fluid from the peritoneal and ovarian surfaces. Variety of chemical mediators like cytokines, Variety of chemical mediators like cytokines.

 

 

 

Management - The management of OHSS is mainly supportive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polycystic ovarian syndrome: PCOS is characterized by chronic anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries, but it does not typically present with sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness associated with enlarged ovaries having large cysts as seen in OHSS.

 

Option C. Theca lutein cysts: These cysts are associated with molar pregnancies and multiple gestations, often presenting with high levels of hCG but not typically with the acute symptoms and clinical scenario described here.

 

Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: This is a type of ovarian tumor that does not present with the acute symptoms and ultrasound findings characteristic of OHSS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation, with symptoms including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness, often visible on ultrasound as enlarged ovaries with large cysts.

questions.text: Artery supplying near marked structure is (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior interventricular artery

 

The anterior interventricular artery, also known as the left anterior descending artery (LAD), supplies the anterior portion of the interventricular septum. This artery runs along the anterior interventricular groove and is critical in providing blood to the front part of the heart, including the septum and the left ventricle. The LAD is often referred to as the "widowmaker" artery because blockage of this artery can lead to severe myocardial infarction, which is often fatal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left circumflex artery: This artery supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle but does not supply the anterior interventricular septum.

 

Option B. Left marginal artery: This artery branches off the circumflex artery and supplies the left ventricle's lateral wall, but it does not supply the interventricular septum.

 

Option D. Posterior interventricular artery: This artery supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum but not the anterior portion. It runs in the posterior interventricular groove.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum and is critical for heart function, making it a key vessel in coronary circulation.

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day she came back with fever, tachycardia and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. Diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cortical vein thrombosis

 

  • The given clinical situation likely suggests Cortical Vein Thrombosis.
  • Cortical Vein thrombosis
    • Risk factors:
      • Pregnancy and puerperium
      • Oral contraceptives
      • Pro thrombotic conditions
    • Clinical presentation
      • Highly variable
      • Headache is the most common symptom.
      • With or without
      • Vomiting
      • Papilledema
      • Focal deficits
    • Investigation
      • Brain MRI with MR venography - most sensitive
      • CT - normal in 30 % of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Subarachnoid hemorrhage unlikely as there are no focal deficits

 

Option B. Meningitis: Meningitis would have presented with neck rigidity / photophobia and early papilledema goes against acute meningitis.

 

Option C. Acute Migraine: Acute Migraine does not present with seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cortical/ Cerebral vein thrombosis should be thought of in a patient with headache and seizures/ other neurological deficits following delivery

questions.text: Where will be the level of the uterus 48 hours after delivery?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2.5 cm below umbilicus

 

  • Following delivery, the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus
  • it remains at level of umbilicus for 24 hours. Following this, it involutes
  • It involutes 1.25 cm/ day form the 2nd day onwards
  • So, after 48 hours (2 days) post-delivery, the uterus will be felt 2.5 cm breadth below the umbilicus
  • It becomes a pelvic organ (no longer abdominally palpable) by 10-14 days
  • It becomes the size of a non-pregnant uterus by 6 weeks
  • alternatively, it reduces by 1 finger breadth / day from 2nd day post partum, till it becomes pelvic organ by 10-14 days

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterus will be 2.5 cm below umbilicus on the second-day post-delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 169, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of thumb after supracondylar fracture is due to the involvement of? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anterior interosseous nerve

 

Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joint of the thumb, is due to the involvement of the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN). This is a branch of the median nerve. It runs down the forearm along with the anterior interosseous artery.

 

It supplies the deep muscles of the anterior (flexor) compartment of the forearm. Specifically, it provides innervation to the flexor pollicis longus (which flexes the interphalangeal joint of the thumb), the radial half of the flexor digitorum profundus, and the pronator quadratus. Injury to this nerve can lead to the inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb and the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers, leading to the characteristic "pinch sign" or "OK sign" presentation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve: It arises from the ulnar nerve after it passes the flexor retinaculum in the wrist. The deep branch is mainly motor in function.

 

  • This nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles (muscles of the little finger), the ulnar two lumbricals, all the interossei (both palmar and dorsal), and adductor pollicis. It does not have any role in the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Option B. Median Nerve: This nerve originates from both the medial and lateral cords of the brachial plexus. It travels down the arm and forearm and goes through the carpal tunnel at the wrist.

 

  • It supplies most of the flexors in the forearm and several muscles in the hand, including the thenar muscles (muscles of the thumb). But the flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb is more specifically due to the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve, not the main trunk of the median nerve.

 

Option C. Posterior Interosseous Nerve: It is a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve. It travels in the forearm between the superficial and deep layers of muscles.

 

  • This nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. It's not involved in flexion movements and hence, not responsible for the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexion of thumb occurs at 2 joints:

 

  1. IP joint: Flexor pollicis longs (FPL) supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the median nerve, C7 and C8).
  2. MCP joint: Flexor pollicis brevis (FPB supplied by the recurrent motor branch of the median nerve.

 

Most commonly injured nerve in SCH fracture: AIN > Median > Radial > Ulnar (AMRU)

 

  • Deep branch of ulnar nerve → ulnar claw hand
  • Posterior interosseous nerve → innervates the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. Weakness or paralysis of these muscles can cause difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers

questions.text: According to wound ballistics, A gunshot wound showing burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound, can be classified as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close shot entry wound

 

Burning (heat of the gases), blackening (deposition of soot) and tattooing (unburned powder particles embedding into the skin) are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds do not show burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are usually larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They show a clean entry hole.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Exit wounds from distant shots also do not show these features and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in chronic arsenic poisoning except? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Luminous vomit

 

Luminous vomiting is a feature of yellow phosphorus poisoning, not arsenic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raindrop pigmentation: This is a characteristic skin finding in chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Option B. Peripheral neuritis: Peripheral neuritis is a common neurological manifestation of chronic arsenic exposure.

 

Option C. Mees line: Mees lines (transverse white lines on nails) are indicative of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features seen in chronic arsenic poisoning:

 

1. Peripheral neuropathy (neuritis):         

It can occur in Arsenic , Thallium , Mercury, and Lead.                                  

Lead: Mainly motor, little bit sensory neuropathy                                                     

Arsenic, Thallium, mercury: mainly sensory, little bit motor neuropathy 

 

2) Skin symptoms:

- Hypopigmentation initially

- Rain Drop Pigmentation as shown below

 

 

- Peculiar skin rash – resembles Addison’s disease , Fading measles rash

- Hyperkeratosis of palms & soles as shown below:

 

3) Nails: Aldrich Mees Lines

Transverse whitish lines on nails (seen is Arsenic, and Thallium)

 

 

 

4) Hair: Alopecia seen in Mercury, Arsenic, Thallium (Mnemonic: Hair on MAT)

 

5) GIT: Vomiting , Diarrhoea , pain abdomen

 

6) Liver: Jaundice , Hepatomegaly , Fatty liver , Cirrhosis

 

7) Blackfoot disease: Coagulation in Peripheral blood vessels leading to Gangrene of periphery

 

8) Malignancy of almost any body part

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in placenta previa? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warning bleeds

 

Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment, either over or close to the internal cervical os. Key features of placenta previa include:

 

  • Warning bleeds: Also known as sentinel bleeds, are sudden-onset, recurrent, painless vaginal bleeding episodes that typically begin in the third trimester or during labor.
  • Soft, non-tender uterus: The abdominal examination reveals a soft and non-tender uterus, with the fundal height proportionate to the gestational age.
  • Normal fetal heart rate: The fetal heart rate is usually normal unless there is severe bleeding due to a large separation.
  • Malpresentations are common: Due to the lower placement of the placenta.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed via transabdominal sonography or transvaginal sonography, which is safe and more accurate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark painful bleeding: This is characteristic of placental abruption, not placenta previa. Placental abruption presents with painful, dark vaginal bleeding due to the premature separation of the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine tenderness: Uterine tenderness is also a feature of placental abruption, where the uterus becomes firm and tender due to bleeding and clot formation behind the placenta.

 

Option D. Increased large uterine size: This is not a specific feature of placenta previa. Uterine size in placenta previa is proportionate to the gestational age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa typically presents with painless, recurrent vaginal bleeding (warning bleeds) in the third trimester or during labor, with a soft, non-tender uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg1940, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 307

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient. During emergency resuscitation, he is administered a 20% Intralipid injection, leading to stabilization of his symptoms. Based on the treatment provided, what was the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST)

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is specifically used to treat local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), a condition that can occur when a local anesthetic, such as bupivacaine or lidocaine, is accidentally injected into the bloodstream or when an excessive dose is administered. This leads to systemic toxicity, presenting with severe neurological and cardiovascular symptoms, including seizures, arrhythmias, and cardiovascular collapse.

 

Pathophysiology of LAST and Intralipid Use:

 

  1. Mechanism of Toxicity: Local anesthetics can interfere with cardiac and neural conduction when they enter the circulation in high concentrations, leading to CNS symptoms like seizures and severe cardiovascular effects such as arrhythmias and hypotension.
  2. Role of Intralipid: Intralipid acts as a “lipid sink,” binding the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules in the bloodstream, thereby reducing their availability at their sites of action in the heart and central nervous system. This helps reverse the toxic effects and stabilizes the patient.
  3. Clinical Use of Intralipid: In cases of LAST, rapid administration of a 20% lipid emulsion can be life-saving, effectively reducing the plasma concentration of the local anesthetic and mitigating its effects on the cardiovascular and nervous systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial infarction: This condition is treated with reperfusion therapy, antiplatelets, and anticoagulants, not Intralipid.

 

Option C. Anaphylactic shock: This is managed with epinephrine, antihistamines, and corticosteroids, not lipid emulsion therapy.

 

Option D. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Management includes insulin, fluids, and electrolyte correction, without any role for Intralipid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is the treatment of choice for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), where it acts as a lipid sink to sequester local anesthetics from critical tissues. Understanding the clinical presentation of LAST and the role of Intralipid is crucial in emergency settings to prevent severe neurological and cardiovascular complications.

choices.text: Discontinue the packet and start an alternate method of contraception
Take 4 tablets the next day, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h
Take the next pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h
Take the next pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining tablets

questions.text: Reema Devi, A 28y newly married woman presents to your sub center for contraceptive advice. She is started on Oral Contraceptive Pills. She presents after 2 weeks with a history of missing 4 tablets on different days in the first 2 weeks of the cycle. What will you advise her? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Take the next pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h

 

 

Missing a pill increases the risk of pregnancy.

 

Management of Missed Pill

 

 

** In this question, she has missed 4 pills in the 1st 2 weeks Hence, she should take the last missed pill, use additional contraception, use emergency contraception, and continue the remaining pack

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue the packet and start an alternate method of contraception: Discontinuing the packet is not advised as it can lead to hormonal imbalance and irregular cycles. An alternate method of contraception can be considered only if the patient prefers to switch, but it is not an immediate solution for the current cycle's missed pills.

 

Option B. Take 4 tablets the next day, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give emergency pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 hours: Taking 4 tablets the next day is excessive and unnecessary. The correct approach is to take the last missed pill and continue as usual.

 

Option D. Take the next pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining tablets: This option neglects the need for additional contraception and emergency contraception, which are crucial to prevent pregnancy in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a woman misses multiple oral contraceptive pills, she should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception, and consider emergency contraception if she had intercourse in the last 72 hours.

choices.text: Decrease scavanging of RBC by macrophages

questions.text: What is seen in G6PD deficiency? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease generation of reduced glutathione

 

G6PD deficiency results in reduced production of reduced glutathione (GSH), an important antioxidant in red blood cells. This decrease in GSH levels impairs the cell's ability to neutralize harmful reactive oxygen species (ROS) and, as a result, increases oxidative stress and damage to red blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease membrane lipid peroxidation: G6PD deficiency can lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione levels, which normally help protect red blood cell membranes from oxidative damage. Therefore, a deficiency in G6PD can actually increase membrane lipid peroxidation, making red blood cells more susceptible to damage from oxidative stress.

 

Option C. Decrease NADH generation: G6PD deficiency primarily affects the production of NADPH (not NADH), which is essential for the regeneration of reduced glutathione and the maintenance of antioxidant defenses in red blood cells. NADPH is crucial in protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

 

Option D. Decrease scavenging of RBC by macrophages: G6PD deficiency can actually increase the susceptibility of red blood cells to phagocytosis by macrophages. The oxidative stress and damage to red blood cells caused by G6PD deficiency can lead to the removal of these damaged cells by macrophages, causing hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells).

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency is associated with a decrease in the generation of reduced glutathione , leading to increased oxidative stress and susceptibility of red blood cells to damage and hemolysis.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 185-186

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following US finding is seen. Identify the defect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

 

The given ultrasound image shows an open neural tube defect in the calvaria (skull), which is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Anencephaly: Results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.
    • Ultrasound Signs:
      • Frog eye sign: Absence of cranial calvaria with prominent orbits, resembling the face of a frog.
      • Shower cap sign: Absence of the cranium leading to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue, resembling a shower cap and giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.
    • Prevention: Can be prevented by pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation (5 mg) for at least 3 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: Congenital herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall covered by a membrane. It is different from gastroschisis.

 

Option C. Cystic hygroma: Lymphangioma occurring in the head-neck region.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Protrusion of the brain and membranes through a cranial defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and prominent orbits, detectable by ultrasound as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. It can be prevented with pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 201, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg471

questions.text: The scope of Project MONICA includes: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cardiovascular diseases 

 

Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.

 

The WHO MONICA (MONItoring trends and determinants in CArdiovascular disease) Project was designed to measure trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease mortality and coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease morbidity, and to assess the extent to which these trends are related to changes in known risk factors in different populations in 27 countries (10 years’ period)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scope of Project MONICA is focused on cardiovascular diseases, specifically monitoring trends in coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease and examining the impact of various risk factors on these conditions.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNS

 

DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients. It contains 5% dextrose along with normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride). This combination helps to provide both hydration and glucose, which is essential for energy. Additionally, DNS can help maintain electrolyte balance, which is critical in pediatric patients who are often at risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. In practice, 1 ml of potassium chloride (KCl) is often added to every 100 ml of DNS to ensure adequate potassium levels, which are vital for proper cellular function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RL (Ringer's Lactate): Ringer's Lactate is often used for fluid resuscitation in adults and in specific conditions such as acidosis. However, it does not contain dextrose, which is necessary for pediatric patients for energy and maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Option C. NS (Normal Saline): Normal Saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is useful for hydration and electrolyte balance but lacks dextrose. Pediatric patients need a source of glucose, especially in cases of prolonged fasting or illness, making NS alone less suitable than DNS.

 

Option D. 5% dextrose: 5% dextrose provides glucose but lacks the electrolytes found in saline. This can lead to imbalances, particularly in pediatric patients, where maintaining proper electrolyte levels is crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Standard deviation

 

  • The formula given represents the standard deviation, which measures the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values.
  • It is the square root of the variance, where the variance is the average of the squared differences from the mean.
  • Standard deviation: This is the deviation of each value from the standard value (mean). It provides insight into the spread of the data points around the mean.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance = (Standard deviation)2. It represents the average of the squared deviations from the mean.

 

Option C. Mean is obtained as the sum of all values divided by the number of values. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Standard deviation is the deviation of each value from the standard value [Mean].

choices.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A
Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal
Point A receives a dose of 7000 cGy
Point B receives a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding radiotherapy is false? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal

 

Point A

 

  • A point 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os.
  • Represents the anatomical location of the ureter.
  • The total dose to point A should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Point B

 

  • A point 3 cm lateral to point A.
  • Represents a dose to the pelvic wall.
  • The dose to point B is about 25 – 30% of the dose to point A (4500 – 6500 cGy).

 

False Statement Explanation

 

  • Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal:
    • This statement is false because Point A is defined as 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, not 5 cm lateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point A in cervical cancer radiotherapy is located 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, and the total dose should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Ref: Page no 350, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition
